abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Local Authorities
            Development Program Project for Senegal were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory, risk to development outcome was
            moderate, Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and
            Borrower performance was moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: the willingness of the Government
            of Senegal (GoS) to move forward with decentralization
            agenda, during and after the project, cannot occur without
            clear frameworks and a strong enabling environment. A
            clearer legal framework is needed to support the development
            of contract management agency (CMA) beyond public works
            executing agency (agence d'execution de travaux
            d'interet public pour l'emploi) (AGETIP) and
            evolution of the municipal development agency (agence de
            developpement municipal) (MDA) as an institution focused on
            financing service delivery in communes (on behalf of the
            government). The use of the municipal contract had proven to
            be relevant all through the project. Although the
            implementation tools (urban, financial, and organizational
            audits) had proven relevant since the urban development and
            decentralization program (UDDP), it is necessary to
            complement them with performance-oriented tools, such as
            scaled public expenditure and financial assessment (PEFA),
            performance-based municipal contracts, set up of minimal
            conditions for equipment maintenance, among others.
            Opportunities for diversified sources of funding should be
            explored, along with a rethinking of the exact role of the MDA.
